Three traits were related to chemical defense (Table 1). The individual amount of defensive secretions (ng/μg; Kruskal-Wallis: n = 286, df = 9, χ 2 = 62.74, p < 0.0001; Table 3; Additional file 3) and its variation within each group (Levene: F 9,276 = 11.25, p < 0.0001; Table 3) differed across all resources. The fraction of regenerating individuals (%; Kruskal-Wallis: N = 100, df = 9, χ 2 = 42.97, P < 0.0001; Table 3; Additional file 3) and their variation within each group (Levene: F 9,90 = 2.99, P = 0.004; Table 3) differed across all resources. Both univariate chemical traits, the individual secretion amount (F 2,283 = 16.84, r
2 = 0.11) and fraction of regenerating individuals (F 2,97 = 11.01, r
2 = 0.19) showed C/N optima curves (Fig. 2; for detailed statistics of linear and nonlinear effect estimates see Table 4). Also, the relative composition (%; Fig. 3a; Table 3) of the seven compounds found in the defensive secretions showed differences among groups (PERMANOVA: pseudo-F 9,276 = 14.01, r
2 = 0.31, p < 0.0001) as well as in multivariate dispersion (=variation; PERMDISP: F 9,276 = 3.91, p < 0.001; see ellipsoid sizes in Fig. 3a) and showed a significant nonlinear response to food C/N-ratios (Table 4).
